Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Bakersfield Terminal. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the propane process at the Bakersfield Terminal will be implemented as needed.
----------

ES – 7.0 THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS
The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The detailed results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP). Administrative controls limit the tank fill capacity to in accordance with NFPA 58 7.4.3.2(B).

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO. The worst-case release scenario is the release of propane from a storage vessel when filled to the greatest amount (85% capacity). The scenario assumes a complete release of 145,180 pounds of propane. The pressure wave (with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure) would extend 0.4 miles (0.9 kilometers). The pressure wave could reach the residential neighborhood located to the west of the site as well as the industrial areas to the east and to the south. There are no sensitive receptors within this blast zone.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO. The alternative release scenario based on the process hazards analysis (or a more plausible potential incident) is a catastrophic release from a full-sized (10,600 gallon water capacity) transport truck. This scenario assumes that the tanker leaks from the bottom-mounted entry valve and that the entire contents of the truck are released to the atmosphere. The alternative release scenario would produce a pressure wave with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure that would extend 0.2 miles (0.3 kilometers). The resulting pressure wave has the potential to impact nearby businesses within this blast radius. There are no residences or sensitive receptors within this blast zone.

ES – 4.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Over the past five years there have been no large or small releases which have resulted in any injuries, property damage or offsite consequences. An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 
----------

ES – 5.0 THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Bakersfield Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures describe the manner of response to a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.

The overall emergency procedure program for the Bakersfield Terminal is coordinated with the Kern County Fire Department. This coordination involves periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives. The Bakersfield Terminal has around the clock communications capability with appropriate officials and emergency response organizations. This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. The facility’s emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. 
The emergency response program is updated, when necessary, based on modifications made to the plant facilities.

CONTRACTOR SAFETY. The Bakersfield Terminal uses contractors during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. The Bakersfield Terminal staff evaluates and qualifies contractors who will work on the systems and equipment. Bakersfield Terminal has procedures in place to ensure that contractors 
-  perform their work in a safe manner.
-  have appropriate knowledge and skills.
-  are aware of the hazards of their workplace.
-  understand what they should do in the event of an emergency.
-  understand and follow site specific safety rules; and 
-  inform plan personnel of any hazards that they find while performing their work. 

Effective implementation of the contractor safety program is accomplished by providing contractors with an orientation session that covers (1) a process overview, (2) information about the safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements and (4) safe work practices prior to beginning their work. 
-----

E-START-UP SAFETY REVIEW. The Bakersfield Terminal conducts a pre-start-up safety review prior to the operating equipment or systems following a modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the pre-start-up safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for start-up prior to placing the equipment in service. 
-----
COMPLIANCE AUDITS. Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Plant operations and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to operations or facility management for resolution. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 
-----
INCIDENT INVESTIGATION. The Bakersfield Terminal has procedures in place that require prompt investigation of incidents that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in, a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendation(s) to prevent a recurrence and presents these results to the business management team for resolution. 
-----
EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION. The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.
-----
HOT WORK PERMIT. Regarding hot work that may occur on or near the propane process, the Bakersfield Terminal has developed a written contractor evaluation program and a Hot Work Permit program to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements. al release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. 

The Bakersfield Terminal has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the process equipment. 

The training program is comprised of the following:
-  Initial employee training.
-  Periodic refresher training (provided at least every three years).
-  Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.
-  Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and
-  Training records for each employee.
-----
MECHANICAL INTEGRITY. The maintenance program at the Bakersfield Terminal is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The Bakersfield Terminal has well established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment. The basic aspects of this program include (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting equipment deficiencies. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. 

Equipment inspections are conducted on a monthly or quarterly basis. The frequency of the inspection is based upon regulatory framework impacting the system or subsystem. 
-----
MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE. The Bakersfield Terminal employs a management of change (MOC) process that requires changes to various systems or items, such as process equipment, technology, procedures, and other facility functions, be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. This program ensures that the safety of the facility is not compromised by the change. Operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on any changes as part of the MOC process.

SAFETY INFORMATION. Kiva Energy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain a safe operating process. These documents address chemical properties. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure. Treatment considerations is provided in safety data sheets (SDS’s).

Kiva Energy also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the safe normal operations and emergency shutdown of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings and electrical rating of equipment.
-----
PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS. Kiva Energy conducted a hazard review of the operations at the Bakersfield Terminal. The hazard review employed the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOPS) methodology and a Checklist method analysis. The plant operator and operations management identified and evaluated hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team made recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.
-----
OPERATING PROCEDURES. The Bakersfield Terminal maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as (1) start­up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown and (6) initial start-up of a new process. These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and provide the basis for training new operators. Operating procedures include applicable safety precautions that must be taken in the operation of the facility. The procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The review and certification process involves both operators and technical staff.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ES – 1.0 FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of Kiva Energy – LP Terminal, LLC Bakersfield Terminal located at 4937 Standard Street in Bakersfield, California, are committed to the prevention of an accidental release of odorized, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, propane). If an accidental release should occur, the facility staff are prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Response Program (ERP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.
----------

ES – 2.0 FACILITY INFORMATION
- The Facility is a bulk, hydrocarbon storage and handling facility that receives LPG by rail cars and trucks. The liquefied petroleum gas is stored in the facility’s 35 aboveground, pressurized storage tanks prior to being loaded into DOT approved delivery trucks (including those owned by Kiva Energy as well as third-party distributors). The 35 tanks are interconnected into 7 groups of 5 vessels. 

- A propane compressor is used to create a pressure differential between the rail cars or trucks being unloaded and the receiving vessels. The differential pressure “pushes” the LPG from the tank cars or trucks into the storage vessels. 

- The propane stored in the aboveground propane storage vessels (identified below) is transferred to DOT approved LPG transportation trucks of approximately 10,600 gallons or smaller bobtail propane delivery trucks of approximately 2,500 gallons through the use of a liquid propane pump. The storage vessels are protected by an automatic fire protection system (a deluge system) that would activate and automatically initiate a response from the local fire department in the event of a fire within the storage yard.
